title: Database Connection Pool Exhausted
description: The primary database connection pool ran out of connections during peak traffic hours. During resolution discovered that John Smith (john.smith@company.com) made recent changes to the connection timeout settings.

timeline_events.author: Team Lead
timeline_events.description: Assigned to Sarah Johnson at sarah.johnson@company.com

timeline_events.author: Sarah Johnson
timeline_events.description: Found recent config changes by John Smith (john.smith@company.com). Checking if this caused connection leaks.

timeline_events.author: Sarah Johnson
timeline_events.description: Discovered root cause: John's changes increased max connections but didn't account for our Kubernetes pod scaling. Will coordinate with DevOps team.

timeline_events.author: Sarah Johnson
timeline_events.description: Applied hotfix with proper connection pooling settings. Monitoring shows recovery.

timeline_events.author: Sarah Johnson
timeline_events.description: All metrics back to normal. Post-incident review scheduled for tomorrow.

custom_fields.root_cause: Configuration change by John Smith didn't account for Kubernetes auto-scaling

analysis.root_cause: Recent database configuration changes by John Smith (john.smith@company.com) increased max connections from 50 to 200, but didn't account for Kubernetes horizontal pod scaling which could create up to 10 pods Ã— 200 connections = 2000 total connections, exceeding database capacity.
contributing_factors: Lack of coordination between DevOps and Platform teams
Missing capacity planning in configuration review process
Insufficient monitoring of connection pool metrics
lessons_learned: Need better cross-team communication for infrastructure changes
Should implement capacity impact analysis for config changes
Add connection pool monitoring to dashboards
